name: Straw-necked Ibis
description: Its species name comes from the elongated feathers on its neck, which resemble straw in both color and texture.
spread_note: Australia, New Guinea, parts of Indonesia
reproduction: Females lay 2–5 eggs; incubation lasts 24–26 days
attractions: Its beak serves as a probe: it uses it to search crevices, shallow muddy water, and mud for small animals it feeds on. They nest in large colonies, sometimes numbering thousands of individuals. It is the most widespread and abundant Australian ibis.
breeding: We have kept them since 2012, with the first chicks raised in 2014.
